comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: The group is interesting and the man in hat fifth from left could be Sir Horace Plunkett; but it is unlikely the Congested Districts Board travelled in a group of this size.  Sir Horace Plunkett came twice to the Butler Arms Hotel in Waterville, Co Kerry in 1891, just after he was appointed to the CDB, but there was nobody with him.  The picture has great clarity and is likely to have been taken on some special occasion that will yet be identified.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Edward, PoW was in Ashford Castle in 1905...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In July 1895 the Royal Society of Antiquities put on a cruise to Galway and the West of Ireland. The Belfast Newsletter had daily updates of its progress. On July 10th it reported on the landing at Clare Island. A little village and pier lay nestled at the foot of an encircling hill, looking very pretty; a large square slated house stood a little way from the village, which everyone took to be the priest's house, but a good glass revealed to me one of the R.I.C. marching across the hill from the barrack, who was, no doubt, greatly wondering from whence the great ship had come, and what her mission was to Clare Island. The ship's boats were soon launched and the eager passengers were thronging down to take their seats. The two principal objects we had to see were Grace O'Malley's Castle, built in the reign of Queen Elizabeth,and a Carmelite monastery. [Background stuff on Grace O'Malley skipped] The photographers set to work, and quite a number of good pictures of the buildings were taken. I wonder if the tourists in the picture are members of the Royal Society of Antiquities? The complete article can be read here . It goes into great detail about the economy and life on the island as it was in 1895.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Grania Wael's Castle maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,471474,785115,7,3 Edward, Prince of Wales visited Ireland before he became King Edward VII in 1901.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Reynold's Newspaper (London) May 6th 1900: PRINCE'S TOUR ROUND IRELAND The details of the Prince of Wales' s contemplated yachting tour in the autumn along the West Coast of Ireland are being filled in. Having touched at Belfast he will visit Sligo, Westport, and Galway, landing on Tory Island, Clare Island, Achill, and Arran on his way

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Another picture with a Joycean link - her grace o'malice or the prankquean of Finnegans Wake. Incidentally shouldn't the title be on Clare ISLAND rather than IRELAND or is it deliberate?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Edward, Prince of Wales and lookalike.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Hmmm. Bertie seems to have planned a trip to Clare Island in late 1900, but the court circulars in the Times (London) don't mention it - numerous trips to Newmarket and at least one to Scotland but none to Ireland. Perhaps it was shelved because of the declining health of his mother? As king he visited Ireland in July 1903. It was planned to sail the royal yacht slowly between Achill and Clare Island, BUT At the appointed time a large crowd of islanders, many of whom had travelled a distance of 15 miles in boats, assembled in Achill Island in expectation of seeing the yacht pass before noon. Unfortunately, as the sea was running high and a thick mist prevailed the vessel could not come so close to the dangerous shore and passed by unseen out at sea. The Times(London) 30th July 1903

comment.author: 44288006@N03
comment._content: This is not Carraigahowley or Rockfleet Castle (as it is also known). Rockfleet is another Granuaile castle but it is near Newport and not on Clare island. I expect you will have pictures of it in your archive. It is still there and in very good condition too!
